page.title: 12Orton Rigg
page.content: This small hamlet one mile south of Great Orton has several old houses dating back to 1825. Some have been built on the foundations of old houses. Others were built in the 1960's. Three new houses are under construction. The chief occupation is farming. Hay, silage, marigolds, barley, oil-seed rape and kale are grown. These are grown in fields known as Fallow Field, Low Meadow, The Pond, and Footpath Field. Suffolk, Southdown, Cheviot and Romney sheep are kept. Herefords, Aberdeen Angus, Ayrshire and Fresian cattle are bred for meat and milk. White Leg-horn, Moran, Game Fowl and Rhode Island Red are the types of poultry kept. Other animals are goats & pigs.The populat- ion is 25. At the entrance to Orton Rigg is a large piece of common land once used by farmers, now a grass area
